awd_titl_txt: Distribution of Roots of Random Functions
awd_abstract_narration:
Random polynomials occur naturally in various areas of physics and mathematics, such as in quantum chaotic systems and approximation theory. The study of random polynomials has applications in computer science and engineering. In addition, studying roots of high-degree polynomials is an important area of mathematics that is useful in both pure and applied sciences. The goal of this research project is to study fundamental questions concerning the distribution of roots of random polynomials and, more generally, random functions.  
 
This project contains three research programs that address questions in the field of random functions. In the first program, the investigator plans to establish local universality for random orthogonal polynomials and derive the mean number of real roots for general distributions. The second program aims to study the variance and the Central Limit Theorem for the number of real roots of various classical models of random functions. The goal of the third program is to further the understanding of the connection between the growth of the coefficients and the growth of the number of real roots. To approach these questions, the investigator will develop the local universality method and build on different tools in analysis and probability. The project will also address several questions regarding the mixing time of Markov Chains and the phase transition of the contact process, an important model for the spread of diseases in communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the period starting 07/01/2023 and ending 01/31/2024, under the support of the NSF grant, I have finished one project on the concentration of roots of the Kac polynomials (joint with Hao Can) in which we established polynomial tail bounds, which are optimal, for the bulk of roots. For the whole real line, we establish sub-optimal tail bounds. 

 

Additionally, I made significant progress on the following on-going projects. Firstly, with my graduate student, Phuc Lam, we studied the non-universality behavior of the number of real roots of the classical Kac polynomials. While it is well-known that the leading term in the asymptotic behavior of this number is universal, the next term is numerically shown to be non-universal. One of the key difficulties to understanding this phenomenon is the behavior of roots near 0, which has been a significant challenge in the field to get precise bounds. We came up with new ideas concerning Gaussian perturbation to solve this problem.

 

Secondly, with Phuc and a 10-grader Iris Yang, we provided opimal upper and lower bounds for the survival time of the SIRS epidemic models on large hubs, confirming a previous conjecture and heuristics by researchers in 2016. Since understanding the temporal behavior on local neighborhoods is crucial to the study on large networks, this is a promising first step for future research. 

 

Next, with Krishnapur, we derived a family of polynomials that give rise to the interpolation of the number of real roots. Among previously known models, this number if either small (of order at most log n), or large (at least square root n) where n is the degree. Our result makes a good progress in understanding the concensation behavior of roots and the complex relationship between the root distribution and the coefficients. 

 

Next, with Jurgen Angst and Guillaume Poly, for the first time, we proved universality for the number of real roots of polynomials with dependence coefficients that are not necessarily Gaussian. We devised novel method to study the dependence case which open the doors to answering many open problems in this area.

 

With my undergraduate students Hunter Zonnenberg and Chen Li, and collaborator Du Phan, we are finishing a paper for publication where we proposed an algorithm to detect communities on large networks utilyzing epidemic features. We show that our method outperfoms competing algorithms in the level of accuracy. Our work has potential applications in health care and other domains where propagations on networks are involved.

 

During this period, I gave a talk at the Southeastern Probability Conference which took place at University of Virginia in Charlottesville, VA on August 14-15, 2023.
